description.summary: A bobcat-like creature with thorny fur and a spiny tail, said to slash cacti to drink their fermented sap, becoming intoxicated and howling through the desert night.
description.full: The Cactus Cat is a fearsome critter from American lumberjack folklore, adapted for the southwestern deserts. This cat-sized creature sports thorny, cactus-like fur and a branched tail covered in sharp spines. According to the tales, it roams the desert at night slashing cacti with its spine-covered front legs, allowing the sap to ferment. Days later, it returns to drink the fermented juice, becoming wildly drunk and producing unearthly screams and howls. The Cactus Cat is a classic example of occupational folklore used by experienced workers to haze newcomers with absurd tall tales presented as local hazards.

etymology.meaning: Named for its cactus-like spines and desert habitat

related_phenomena.name: Wampus Cat
related_phenomena.description: Another fearsome feline from Appalachian folklore

features.description: Body covered in cactus-like spines and thorns
Branching tail covered in sharp spines
Front legs protected by bony guards for slashing cacti

physical.morphology: Resembles a bobcat but covered entirely in protective spines similar to cactus needles

abilities.description: Uses spined legs to slash cacti and release sap
Can consume large amounts of fermented cactus sap

behavior.disposition: neutral when sober, aggressive when drunk

range.description: Southwestern United States deserts, particularly Arizona

origins.cultural_roots: American occupational folklore from lumber camps
origins.folklore_connections: Part of fearsome critters tradition used to haze greenhorn workers

folklore.beliefs: Never believed literally; created for entertainment and hazing newcomers

literature: Fearsome Creatures of the Lumberwoods by William T. Cox (1910)
